questions.text: A 34 year-old lady has had a lump in her breast for 2 years. On examination, a 6x4 cm mass is palpated. Dimpling of the skin and bloody discharge from the nipple is present. The lesion is invading the pectoralis major muscle. Ipsilateral Level I and Level II matted axillary lymph nodes present. There was no distant metastasis. What is the TNM staging?
questions.solution:
Incorrect Choices Explanation

  • Choice A: T4bN1M0 - T4b refers to ulceration or skin involvement with edema (inflammatory breast cancer), but this case is more consistent with a large mass and invasion into the pectoralis major, which is better classified as T3. N1 refers to 1-3 axillary lymph nodes, but this case has matted nodes in Level I and II, which makes N2 more appropriate.
  • Choice C: T4aN1M0 - T4a refers to invasion of the chest wall, but in this case, the tumor involves the pectoralis major (muscle), which is a hallmark of T3. N1 would be incorrect here as the patient has matted nodes in Levels I and II, corresponding to N2.
  • Choice D: T2N1M1 - T2 refers to tumors >2 cm but ≤5 cm, but the tumor in this case is larger than 5 cm, making T2 incorrect. N1 (1-3 axillary lymph nodes) would not be accurate because the axillary nodes are matted (N2). M1 is incorrect because there is no evidence of distant metastasis.

Key Takeaway - The correct staging is T3N2M0. The tumor is large (6x4 cm, T3), involves matted axillary lymph nodes (N2), and has no distant metastasis (M0).

choices.text: Normal DEXA scan rules out need for surgery
SESTAMIBI followed by focused parathyroidectomy to be done

questions.text: A 34 year-old male investigation revealed serum calcium to be 12.8 mg/dL (N: 8.5-10.25 mg/dL) and with raised PTH. On ultrasonography there is a 1.5x1.5 mass detected on the right lower lobe of the thyroid gland. Which of the following is true regarding this condition?
questions.solution:
Minimally invasive approaches are based on the principle that over 80% of individuals with PHPT have a single adenoma. Although there is no strict definition of the procedure, it commonly refers to the removal of a localised abnormal parathyroid gland through an incision less than 3 cm in length. The term encompasses open approaches (central and lateral incisions) and video-assisted and radio-guided parathyroidectomies.

The need to convert from a focused to a cervical exploration may be guided by the use of intraoperative PTH measurements. Routine use is, however, controversial owing to high false-positive and false-negative rates. The basic concept is that the half-life of circulating PTH is 3-5 minutes and there should therefore be a significant drop detected in the plasma PTH following resection of a single adenoma. If no such drop is detected, then multigland disease may be suspected and conversion to a bilateral neck exploration should be considered. The Miami criteria were developed to determine the extent of resection. A drop in the PTH into the normal range and to less than half the maximum preoperative PTH at 10 minutes appears to accurately predict single-gland disease.

The use of sestamibi (2-methoxy-2-methylpropylisonitrile [MIBI]) for parathyroid localisation was first described in 1989 and is now regarded as the most accurate and reliable method for imaging the parathyroid glands. It is safe and reproducible and, while it has a sensitivity and specificity similar to ultrasonography, it may image glands in ectopic positions better. Sestamibi accumulates in mitochondria and therefore washes out at differential rates depending on the number of mitochondria within individual tissues. Parathyroid adenomas often have a high concentration of oxyphilic cells with high mitochondrial content. These retain tracer, and adenomas are therefore associated with a slow washout when compared with the thyroid gland. There are three different protocols for sestamibi scanning: single-isotope dual-phase scan, dual-isotope subtraction imaging and single-photon emission computed tomography (SPECT). The sensitivity and specifcity of sestamibi, regardless of the protocol used, are 79% and 90%, respectively. False positives are rare but may arise from some solid thyroid nodules, such as Hürthle cell nodules, that are associated with high oxyphilic content. These can be reduced by the addition of a thyroid-specific radioactive tracer, such as 99Tc-pertechnetate and subsequent subtraction images

Incorrect Choices Explanation

  • Choice A: Normal DEXA scan rules out need for surgery - A normal DEXA scan does not rule out the need for surgery. The primary indication for surgery in hyperparathyroidism is symptomatic hypercalcemia, not bone mineral density.
  • Choice C: No surgery required, only surveillance - Surgery is indicated for symptomatic hyperparathyroidism or for conditions like hypercalcemia that may result in complications (e.g., kidney stones, osteoporosis). Surveillance is not adequate for this patient's condition given the hypercalcemia and raised PTH.
  • Choice D: Creatinine clearance > 80 ml/min mandates surgery = Creatinine clearance is not a criterion that mandates surgery. Surgery is based on symptomatic hypercalcemia and other factors, such as the presence of complications (e.g., kidney stones, fractures) rather than just creatinine clearance.

Key Takeaway - SESTAMIBI followed by focused parathyroidectomy is the correct approach for managing a parathyroid adenoma in the setting of primary hyperparathyroidism with hypercalcemia.

choices.text: Total thyroidectomy with modified radical neck dissection

questions.text: A 40-year-old patient who's a known case of Hodgkin's lymphoma with a previous history of irradiation presents with right-sided thyroid swelling. FNAC reveals papillary carcinoma of the thyroid and there is no lymph node involvement. What is the next step in management?
questions.solution:
Reoperation for recurrent nodular goitre is more difcult and hazardous and, for this reason, an increasing number of thyroid surgeons favour total thyroidectomy in younger patients. However, when the first operation comprises unilateral lobectomy alone for asymmetric goitre, reoperation and completion total thyroidectomy is straightforward if required for progression of nodularity in the remaining lobe. Total lobectomy and total thyroidectomy have the additional advantage of being therapeutic for incidental carcinomas

Incorrect Choices Explanation

  • Choice B: Total thyroidectomy with modified radical neck dissection - A modified radical neck dissection is not necessary in this case since there is no lymph node involvement, as confirmed by the FNAC. The neck dissection is typically reserved for cases with evidence of lymph node metastasis.
  • Choice C: Hemi-thyroidectomy - Hemi-thyroidectomy, or lobectomy, is not ideal in this case due to the patient's history of irradiation and the nature of the papillary carcinoma, which may present in both lobes. A total thyroidectomy provides more definitive management and decreases the risk of recurrence.
  • Choice D: Hemi-thyroidectomy with modified radical neck dissection - As mentioned, hemi-thyroidectomy alone is not sufficient for this patient's papillary carcinoma. Additionally, modified radical neck dissection is not needed since there is no lymph node involvement.

Key Takeaway - Total thyroidectomy is the appropriate management for papillary carcinoma of the thyroid in a patient with a history of irradiation, providing a more definitive approach with reduced recurrence risk.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a component of the MEN2B syndrome?
questions.solution:
This has a prevalence of 0.2 in 100 000. MEN 2B is also caused by RET mutations, half of which are de novo.A variant of MEN 2 characterised by an aggressive and early-onset form of MTC (100%), PPGL (59%), marfanoid habitus and ganglioneuromatosis of the oral mucosa and gut. MTC is associated with rapid growth and a poor prognosis

Incorrect Choices Explanation

  • Choice A: Medullary thyroid carcinoma - Medullary thyroid carcinoma (MTC) is a hallmark of MEN2B. It is present in all cases and is associated with aggressive, early-onset disease and poor prognosis.
  • Choice B: Marfanoid habitus - Marfanoid habitus, which includes features such as tall stature, long limbs, and hypermobile joints, is a characteristic feature of MEN2B.
  • Choice C: Mucosal ganglioneuromatosis - Mucosal ganglioneuromatosis, which involves the development of ganglioneuromas in the mucosal lining of the gastrointestinal tract and oral mucosa, is a distinguishing feature of MEN2B.

Key Takeaway - Parathyroid hyperplasia is not part of MEN2B; this syndrome is instead characterized by MTC, pheochromocytomas, marfanoid habitus, and mucosal ganglioneuromatosis.

questions.text: A 20-year-old male patient presented with a history of occasional palpitations, High BP, and headache. The patient is diagnosed with pheochromocytoma. Which of the following will be the preferred first investigation?
questions.solution:
The diagnosis of PPGL is confirmed by elevated catecholamine metabolites (metanephrines) in plasma and/or raised 24-hour urinary excretion of fractionated metanephrines. Metanephrines are produced as a result of intratumour conversion of catecholamines by the enzyme catecholamine- O-methyltransferase. Measurement of plasma and urinary metanephrines is more sensitive (99% and 97%, respectively) than plasma and urinary catecholamine measurement (86% and 84%, respectively). Measurements of one or more of these substances that are four times greater than the upper limit of the reference range are 100% diagnostic. Plasma dopamine can be regarded as a marker of tumour burden in malignant PPGL

Incorrect Choices Explanation

  • Choice A: USG Abdomen - Ultrasound is not the most sensitive or specific test for diagnosing pheochromocytoma. While it can be used for imaging, it is less effective than CT or MRI for detecting adrenal masses.
  • Choice B: MRI - Abdomen - MRI is useful for locating pheochromocytomas, especially in difficult cases, but it is not the first-line test for diagnosis. The 24-hour urinary metanephrine test is the initial diagnostic step.
  • Choice D: MIBG - MIBG (metaiodobenzylguanidine) scanning is a specialized imaging technique for localizing pheochromocytomas, particularly in cases of metastatic or extra-adrenal tumors. It is not typically the first step in diagnosis.

Key Takeaway - 24-hour urinary metanephrines is the most sensitive and specific first investigation for diagnosing pheochromocytoma, with elevated levels being diagnostic.

questions.text: The most lethal nerve injury during thyroid surgery:
questions.solution:
Unilateral recurrent laryngeal nerve palsy of sudden onset produces hoarseness, difficulty in swallowing liquids and a weakened cough. These symptoms may be short-lived and the voice may return to normal within a few weeks as the muscles in the opposite vocal fold compensate and move it across the midline to meet the paralysed vocal fold, which usually lies in the paramedian position. Bilateral recurrent laryngeal nerve palsy is an occasional and serious complication of total thyroidectomy.

On anaesthetic reversal, acute dyspnoea occurs as a result of the paramedian position of both vocal folds, which reduce the airway to 2-3 mm and which tend to get sucked together on inspiration. This can be temporarily relieved by positive pressure mask ventilation, but, in severe cases, tracheostomy or intubation is necessary immediately, otherwise death occurs from asphyxia

Incorrect Choices Explanation

  • Choice A: Unilateral recurrent laryngeal nerve injury (partial) - Unilateral recurrent laryngeal nerve injury, even if partial, typically results in hoarseness or weak voice, but the patient is usually not at risk of life-threatening airway obstruction. The unaffected vocal cord may compensate, and the voice often improves within weeks.
  • Choice B: Bilateral recurrent laryngeal nerve injury (partial) - Partial bilateral recurrent laryngeal nerve injury can lead to mild voice changes and may not result in critical airway compromise like complete injury. This is less lethal than a complete injury.
  • Choice C: Unilateral recurrent laryngeal nerve injury (complete) - Complete unilateral recurrent laryngeal nerve injury causes significant hoarseness and voice dysfunction, but it does not pose an immediate risk to the airway or life. The opposite vocal cord can often compensate for the lost function.

Key Takeaway - Bilateral recurrent laryngeal nerve injury (complete) is the most lethal complication in thyroid surgery due to the severe airway obstruction that can result from both vocal cords being paralyzed.

choices.text: Secure airway, give oxygen, insert ICD, secure IV line
Administer IV dextrose followed by NCCT head
Start IV fluids, give atropine, and secure airway
Evaluate for head injury and do CT-Head

questions.text: A 25-year-old male patient with a history of road traffic accident was brought to the emergency department. His GCS was 8/15, oxygen saturation was 85%, BP is 100/60 mmHg, heart rate is 60 bpm. On osculation his right side breath sounds were absent. What is the next step in management?
questions.solution:
Accumulation of blood in a haemothorax can significantly compromise respiratory efforts, compressing the lung and preventing adequate ventilation. Presentation is with haemorrhagic shock, fat neck veins, unilateral absence of breath sounds and dullness to percussion. The initial treatment consists of correcting the hypovolaemic shock, insertion of an intercostal drain and, in some cases, intubation

Incorrect Choices Explanation

  • Choice B: Administer IV dextrose followed by NCCT head - IV dextrose is not appropriate in this case as the primary issue is trauma-related, specifically suspected hemothorax. Additionally, a non-contrast CT head is not the immediate priority in a patient with respiratory compromise and potential hemorrhagic shock.
  • Choice C: Start IV fluids, give atropine, and secure airway - While starting IV fluids and securing the airway are appropriate, atropine is not indicated unless there is bradycardia due to a specific cause such as a vagal response or heart block. The more pressing concern is addressing the hemothorax and its associated shock.
  • Choice D: Evaluate for head injury and do CT-Head - Although head injury should be considered, this patient's immediate life-threatening condition is respiratory distress and shock due to potential hemothorax, not a head injury. The focus should be on stabilizing his breathing and circulation first.

Key Takeaway - Secure airway, give oxygen, insert ICD, and secure IV line is the correct immediate management for a patient with signs of hemothorax and respiratory distress following trauma.

questions.text: A 25-year-old patient sustains a fall from the 2nd floor of the building and is brought to the emergency department. Which of the following is not an adjunct to primary survey?
questions.solution:
Haemodynamically unstable patients on arrival that they need immediate surgical control of their haemorrhage before a CT scan. The most likely sources are abdominal or pelvic bleeding. An immediate chest radio-graph will exclude catastrophic intrathoracic haemorrhage. An immediate pelvic radiograph is essential but should not delay transfer to the operating theatre. A focused abdominal sonography for trauma (FAST) scan (if immediately available) may also be useful in this scenario to locate the major source of haemorrhage

Incorrect Choices Explanation

  • Choice A: X-ray chest AP - A chest X-ray is part of the primary survey to quickly assess for life-threatening conditions like pneumothorax, hemothorax, or cardiac tamponade. This should be performed early in the trauma evaluation.
  • Choice B: Extended FAST - Extended FAST (Focused Assessment with Sonography for Trauma) is a valuable tool during the primary survey to quickly identify intraperitoneal, pleural, or pericardial fluid collections, which can indicate hemorrhage. It is a useful adjunct in the trauma setting.
  • Choice C: X-ray pelvis AP - A pelvic X-ray is important to assess for pelvic fractures, which can be a source of major bleeding. It is an essential part of the primary survey in trauma, especially for patients with significant blunt force injuries.

Key Takeaway - CT abdomen and pelvis is not part of the primary survey in a hemodynamically unstable trauma patient. Immediate management should focus on stabilizing the patient with rapid X-rays and a FAST scan.

questions.text: A middle-aged lady comes with flank pain and painful micturition. The pain was relieved by IV analgesics given at a nearby healthcare centre. The patient is diagnosed with ureteric colic due to ureteric calculi. What is the best diagnostic modality in this case?
questions.solution:
Non-contrast CT (NCCT) is the investigation of choice for the diagnosis of stones. It allows for diagnosis of both radio-opaque and radiolucent stones with the exception of indinavir stones.

Incorrect Choices Explanation

  • Choice A: CECT - Contrast-enhanced CT (CECT) is typically not used for the diagnosis of ureteric calculi unless there is a need to evaluate other aspects such as the presence of any associated complications or anatomical abnormalities. The contrast can interfere with stone visualization, making NCCT a better option.
  • Choice C: USG KUB - Ultrasound (USG) is a non-invasive modality but is less sensitive than NCCT, especially for detecting small stones or those in the distal ureter. It can be useful in assessing complications like hydronephrosis but is not the gold standard for diagnosing ureteric stones.
  • Choice D: Ureteroscopy - Ureteroscopy is a diagnostic and therapeutic procedure used to directly visualize and treat ureteric stones. It is not typically used for initial diagnosis unless there is a need for intervention, as it is invasive and more resource-intensive.

Key Takeaway - NCCT KUB is the best diagnostic modality for diagnosing ureteric calculi due to its high sensitivity and ability to detect both radiopaque and radiolucent stones.

questions.text: Identify the structure on prostate biopsy:
questions.solution:
Corpora amylaceae are tiny calcified lamellated bodies found in the glandular alveoli of the prostates of elderly men and apes, but not in the prostates of animals lower in the phylogenetic scale than anthropoids. Corpora amylaceae are probably the forerunners of endogenous prostatic calculi

Incorrect Choices Explanation

  • Choice B: Psammoma bodies - Psammoma bodies are concentric, calcified structures that are typically associated with certain tumors, such as papillary thyroid carcinoma, ovarian serous carcinoma, and meningiomas. They are not characteristic of the prostate.
  • Choice C: Amyloid - Amyloid deposits are abnormal protein aggregates that can be found in various tissues, including the prostate in conditions such as amyloidosis. However, amyloid is not a common finding on routine prostate biopsy and is distinct from corpora amylacea.
  • Choice D: Corpora arenecea - This appears to be a typographical error. The correct term is corpora amylacea, not corpora arenecea. There is no recognized structure by the name of corpora arenecea in prostate tissue.

Key Takeaway - Corpora amylacea are calcified bodies found in the prostate, particularly in older men, and are considered a normal finding.

Reference: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Corpora_amylacea

choices.text: Dysphasia more to liquids followed by solids
Dysphagia of solids followed by liquids

questions.text: During Ward rounds you see a patient who's admitted with Ca esophagus. What is the most likely presentation of this patient?
questions.solution:
Progressive dysphagia is the most common symptom, related to increasing luminal obstruction by cancer. Early symptoms may include a mild hold-up sensation that, if ignored, will progress from dysphagia to a solid, soft and eventually to a liquid diet. There may often be anorexia, weight loss, odynophagia and regurgitation symptoms. Hoarseness may indicate involvement of either recurrent laryngeal nerve. Aspiration and choking symptoms may be related not only to tumour obstruction but also to the presence of an oesophagus-airway fistula. Choking and cough on drinking water are typical of fistulation and associated haemoptysis is common. Blood loss is less common for squamous cell cancer than adenocarcinoma. Chronic blood loss can lead to iron deficiency anemia. Acute gastrointestinal bleeding can occur, though it is rarely severe, except for aorto-oesophageal fistula, which usually presents with a smaller sentinel bleed followed by massive bleeding that is invariably fatal.

Incorrect Choices Explanation

  • Choice A: Dysphagia more to liquids followed by solids - Dysphagia to liquids occurring before solids is less characteristic of esophageal cancer. This pattern is more commonly seen in conditions like achalasia, where the esophagus fails to properly move food down, and the dysfunction is more prominent with liquids initially.
  • Choice B: Odynophagia - Odynophagia, or painful swallowing, can occur in esophageal cancer but is not the most common presentation. It tends to develop later in the disease process and is more associated with ulcers or advanced tumor involvement.
  • Choice D: Retrosternal chest pain - While retrosternal chest pain can occur, it is not the most common initial symptom of esophageal cancer. Chest pain might be more associated with other causes, such as reflux or tumor involvement affecting nearby structures, but dysphagia remains the hallmark symptom.

Key Takeaway - Dysphagia of solids followed by liquids is the typical progression in esophageal cancer as the tumor gradually obstructs the esophagus, initially affecting solid food and later affecting liquids.

choices.text: Gastrinoma, triangle formed by common bile duct, junction of D2-D3, neck and body of pancreas
Insulinoma, triangle formed by cystic duct, junction of D2-D3, neck and body of pancreas
Gastrinoma, triangle formed by cystic duct, junction of D2-D3, neck and body of pancreas
Gastrinoma, triangle formed by cystic duct, junction of D2-D3, neck and body of pancreas

questions.text: A 30 year old patient with peptic ulcer presents with abdominal pain that is not responding despite treatment in multiple hospitals. He was found to have ulcers in jejunum and ileum. Gastric pH is <2, and gastrin levels are raised after adequate cessation of PPIs are 10 times the normal value. Identify the lesion present and the boundaries of the triangle containing it.
questions.solution:
The vast majority (approximately 90%) occur within the "gastrinoma triangle", an area bounded by the junction of the neck and body of the pancreas medially, the junction of the second and third parts of the duodenum inferiorly and the junction of the cystic and common bile ducts superiorly.

This is an insulin-producing tumour of the pancreas. The aetiology of insulinomas is unknown. They are equally scattered throughout the pancreas

Incorrect Choices Explanation

  • Choice A: Gastrinoma, triangle formed by common bile duct, junction of D2-D3, neck and body of pancreas - While this describes a gastrinoma, the boundary involving the common bile duct is incorrect. The superior boundary of the gastrinoma triangle is actually the junction of the cystic duct and common bile duct, not just the common bile duct alone.
  • Choice B: Insulinoma, triangle formed by cystic duct, junction of D2-D3, neck and body of pancreas - Insulinomas are tumors that produce insulin, but this choice confuses the location and pathology. Insulinomas can occur throughout the pancreas, not in a specific triangle like gastrinomas.
  • Choice D: Insulinoma, triangle formed by common bile duct, junction of D2-D3, neck and body of pancreas - This choice is also incorrect for insulinomas. Insulinomas are scattered throughout the pancreas, and the triangle described does not define their usual location.

Key Takeaway - Gastrinoma typically occurs within the gastrinoma triangle, defined by the cystic duct, the junction of the second and third parts of the duodenum, and the neck/body of the pancreas.

questions.text: Elderly male comes with foul smelling breath and dysphagia. A barium swallow is done. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Zenker's diverticulum is a false pulsion diverticulum as it protrudes posteriorly above the cricopharyngeal sphincter through the natural weak point (the dehiscence of Killian) between the oblique and horizontal fibres of the inferior pharyngeal constrictor. The pathophysiology is believed to involve loss of coordination between pharyngeal contraction and opening of the upper sphincter. When the diverticulum is small, symptoms largely reflect desynchronisation of swallowing with predominantly pharyngeal dysphagia. As the pouch enlarges, it tends to fill with food on eating, and the fundus descends into the mediastinum. Regurgitation of trapped food can occur and lead to aspiration. Another symptom is halitosis. Conventional surgical treatment involves an open left cervical incision (most diverticula point towards the left side) with diverticulectomy and cricopharyngeus myotomy. Another option is diverticular suspension, whereby the diverticulum is dissected and inverted with its apex pointing cranially. This will stop food from entering the pouch. The absence of a suture line lessens the chance of a postoperative leak. A cricopharyngeus myotomy is also an integral part of the surgery. Newer techniques include transoral introduction of a linear stapler to divide the septum in between the diverticulum and the true oesophageal lumen. This creates a common channel, and the myotomy is in effect performed by the stapler transection.

Incorrect Choices Explanation

  • Choice A: Carcinoma Esophagus - While esophageal cancer may present with dysphagia, it does not typically cause foul-smelling breath unless there is an associated infection or aspiration. Additionally, the barium swallow findings would show irregularities or strictures, not the characteristic diverticulum seen in Zenker's.
  • Choice B: Achalasia cardia - Achalasia is characterized by difficulty swallowing, but it is typically associated with a smooth, gradual dilation of the esophagus and failure of the lower esophageal sphincter to relax. Foul-smelling breath may be present due to food stasis, but the barium swallow would show a "bird's beak" appearance, which differs from the diverticular formation seen in Zenker's.
  • Choice D: Tracheoesophageal fistula - Tracheoesophageal fistula often presents with aspiration, choking, and respiratory symptoms, not the isolated dysphagia and halitosis seen with Zenker's diverticulum. Barium swallow would reveal a communication between the trachea and esophagus, which is not characteristic of Zenker's.

Key Takeaway - Zenker's diverticulum typically presents with dysphagia, halitosis, and regurgitation of food. The characteristic findings on a barium swallow include a pouch formation above the cricopharyngeal sphincter.

Reference: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK499996/figure/article-31462.image.f3/

questions.text: You are an intern assisting in laparoscopic surgery and the resident is orienting the intern to the instruments and the operating ports. Your surgeon asks you what is the angle between the camera port and the working Port known as?
questions.solution:
The Azimuth's angle refers to the angle between the camera port and the working port in laparoscopic surgery. This angle is critical in determining the appropriate positioning of the camera to provide optimal visualization and access to the operative field.

Incorrect Choices Explanation

  • Choice A: Manipulation angle - The manipulation angle typically refers to the angle at which surgical instruments are manipulated in relation to the target tissue, not specifically the relationship between the camera and working ports.
  • Choice C: Elevation angle - The elevation angle pertains to the tilt or vertical positioning of the camera or instruments relative to the operative area, rather than the spatial relationship between the camera and working ports.
  • Choice D: Crossing angle - The crossing angle is not a standard term used in laparoscopic surgery to describe the relationship between camera and working ports. This term might be confused with the positioning of instruments during surgery but does not describe the port angle.

Key Takeaway - The angle between the camera port and the working port in laparoscopic surgery is called the Azimuth's angle.

questions.text: A 60-year-old male complains of numbness in lower limbs. On examination Romberg's test is positive with broad based gait and loss of proprioception on both lower limbs. He also has a history of low BP, hypothyroidism and gastrectomy for gastric cancer one year back. Which of the following deficiency can cause the current condition?
questions.solution:
Vitamin B12 deficiency occurs after total gastrectomy; however, it may be years before megaloblastic anaemia is clinically apparent. Vitamin B12 supplementation after total gastrectomy is essential. Rarely, vitamin B12 deficiency may occur after lesser forms of gastrectomy. In such patients the cause is probably a combination of reduced intrinsic factor production and bacterial colonisation, which results in vitamin B12 being metabolised in the gut, preventing absorption

Incorrect Choices Explanation

  • Choice A: Folic acid deficiency - While folic acid deficiency can cause megaloblastic anemia, it does not typically present with the neurological signs observed in this patient. Folic acid deficiency alone generally does not cause the neuropathy and proprioception loss seen in this case.
  • Choice B: Thiamine deficiency - Thiamine deficiency primarily causes Wernicke's encephalopathy or beriberi, which manifest as confusion, ataxia, and ophthalmoplegia. It does not typically present with proprioception loss and broad-based gait in the lower limbs.
  • Choice D: Transferrin deficiency - Transferrin deficiency is a rare condition related to iron metabolism and would not be the cause of neurological symptoms like numbness, loss of proprioception, and gait abnormalities. This deficiency is unrelated to the patient's presentation.

Key Takeaway - The patient's symptoms of neuropathy, proprioception loss, and positive Romberg's test, along with a history of gastrectomy, are most likely caused by Vitamin B12 deficiency.

questions.text: During separation of spleen from the stomach while performing splenectomy which artery can be a source of bleeding?
questions.solution:
Midline or transverse left subcostal incision for open splenectomy with the patient in the supine position. Rarely, a thoracoabdominal incision may be necessary for a massive spleen that is adherent to the diaphragm. Passage of a nasogastric tube following induction of the anaesthetic enables the stomach to be emptied. In elective splenectomy, the gastrosplenic ligament is opened and the short gastric vessels are divided. The splenic vessels at the superior border of the pancreas are suture ligated. Division of the posterior leaf of the lienorenal ligament with long curved scissors on the posterior surface of the spleen helps to rotate and deliver the spleen medially into the laparotomy wound along with the tail and body of the pancreas. The posterior surface of the spleen is exposed and the spleen rotated medially along with the tail and body of the pancreas. The pancreas is separated from the hilar vessels, which are normally doubly ligated separately and divided. Accessory splenic tissue in the splenic hilum or omentum should be excluded by a careful search at operation

Incorrect Choices Explanation

  • Choice A: Left gastroepiploic artery - The left gastroepiploic artery runs along the greater curvature of the stomach, and while it is near the spleen, it is not typically the primary source of bleeding when separating the spleen from the stomach. It may be encountered during dissection, but it is not as critical as the short gastric arteries in this context.
  • Choice C: Right gastroepiploic artery - The right gastroepiploic artery supplies the right side of the greater curvature of the stomach and is not involved in the dissection during splenectomy as it is located further from the spleen and stomach junction.
  • Choice D: Splenic artery - The splenic artery is the main artery supplying the spleen itself, and while it can be a source of bleeding during splenectomy, it is not directly involved in the separation of the spleen from the stomach, which is where the short gastric arteries are located.

Key Takeaway - During splenectomy, the short gastric arteries, located in the gastrosplenic ligament, are the primary source of bleeding when separating the spleen from the stomach.

questions.text: Truelove and Witts classification is used for:
questions.solution:
The assessment of the severity of colitis is determined by the frequency of bowel action and the presence of systemic signs of illness, as originally proposed by Truelove and Witts:

  • Mild disease is characterised by fewer than four stools daily, with or without bleeding. There are no systemic signs of toxicity.
  • Moderate disease corresponds to more than four stools daily, but with few signs of systemic illness. There may be mild anaemia. Abdominal pain may occur. Inflammatory markers, including erythrocyte sedimentation rate and C-reactive protein, are often raised.
  • Severe disease corresponds to more than six bloody stools a day and evidence of systemic illness, with fever, tachycardia, anaemia and raised inflammatory markers. Hypoalbuminaemia is common and an ominous finding.
  • Fulminant disease is associated with more than 10 bowel movements daily, fever, tachycardia, continuous bleeding, anaemia, hypoalbuminaemia, abdominal tenderness and distension, the need for blood transfusion and, in the most severe cases, progressive colonic dilation (toxic megacolon). This is a very significant finding, suggestive of disintegrative colitis, and an indication for emergency surgery if colonic perforation is to be avoided.

Incorrect Choices Explanation

  • Choice B: Acute pancreatitis - Acute pancreatitis is classified by other scoring systems such as the Ranson criteria or APACHE II, which assess factors like age, white blood cell count, and organ dysfunction, but Truelove and Witts classification is not used for pancreatitis.
  • Choice C: Acute encephalitis - Acute encephalitis is typically diagnosed and assessed using different criteria, such as clinical findings, CSF analysis, and neuroimaging. The Truelove and Witts classification is not applicable to encephalitis.
  • Choice D: ARDS - Acute Respiratory Distress Syndrome (ARDS) is classified based on oxygenation levels (PaO2/FiO2 ratio), and not by the Truelove and Witts classification, which is designed for ulcerative colitis.

Key Takeaway - The Truelove and Witts classification is used to assess the severity of acute severe ulcerative colitis based on symptoms like stool frequency, bleeding, systemic illness, and inflammatory markers.

questions.text: Match the following diseases with their respective gene mutations:
questions.solution:
Juvenile polyposis (JPS) is an autosomal dominant inherited condition that presents with hamartomatous polyps due to mutations in the BMPR1A, SMAD4 or ENG genes

Key Takeaway

  • The correct gene mutations for each disease are:
    • Familial adenomatous polyposis: APC
    • Juvenile polyposis: SMAD4
    • Tuberous sclerosis: TSC1
    • Peutz-Jeghers syndrome: STK11

choices.text: Serum amylase remains elevated even after 30 days of resolution of acute pancreatitis
Serum lipase is more specific than serum amylase
Increase in level of serum lipase is directly proportional to the severity

questions.text: A 20-year-old male who presents with acute epigastric pain and fever. He has a past history of cholelithiasis. On examination, abdominal guarding and rigidity are present. His serum amylase and lipase are raised and the patient has leukocytosis. What is true regarding his condition?
questions.solution:
Pain is usually experienced first in the epigastrium but may be localised to either upper quadrant or felt diffusely throughout the abdomen. There is radiation to the back in about 50% of patients, and some patients may gain relief by sitting or leaning forwards. The suddenness of onset may simulate a perforated peptic ulcer, while biliary colic or acute cholecystitis can be mimicked if the pain is maximal in the right upper quadrant. Radiation to the chest can simulate myocardial infarction, pneumonia or pleuritic pain. In fact, acute pancreatitis can mimic most causes of the acute abdomen and should seldom be discounted in differential diagnosis. Typically, the diagnosis is made on the basis of the clinical presentation and an elevated serum amylase level. A serum amylase level three times above normal is indicative of the disease. A normal serum amylase level does not exclude acute pancreatitis, particularly if there is delay in presentation. The serum lipase level provides a more sensitive and specific test than amylase

Incorrect Choices Explanation

  • Choice A: Serum amylase remains elevated even after 30 days of resolution of acute pancreatitis - This is incorrect because serum amylase levels typically return to normal within a few days after the resolution of acute pancreatitis. Elevated amylase beyond this period is unusual and should raise suspicion for other conditions.
  • Choice C: >75% patients present with hypercalcemia - This is incorrect because hypercalcemia is not a common feature of acute pancreatitis. In fact, acute pancreatitis may sometimes be associated with hypocalcemia, especially in severe cases.
  • Choice D: Increase in level of serum lipase is directly proportional to the severity - This is incorrect because while serum lipase levels are a useful diagnostic tool, their level does not always correlate directly with the severity of pancreatitis. Other clinical parameters like imaging findings and clinical signs are more reliable for assessing severity.

Key Takeaway - Serum lipase is more specific for diagnosing acute pancreatitis compared to serum amylase, and its elevated levels are more directly linked to the condition itself.

questions.text: Match the following:
questions.solution:
These are tumours of the parafollicular (C cells) derived from the neural crest that are not unlike those of a carcinoid tumour. High levels of serum calcitonin and carcinoembryonic antigen are produced. Calcitonin levels fall after resection and rise again with recurrence, making it a valuable tumour marker in the follow-up of patients with this disease. Choriocarcinoma is almost never seen in childhood. This tumour produces human chorionic gonadotropin (HCG), which can be detected in blood. PGLs are either parasympathetic or sympathetic. Parasympathetic PGLs are sited mainly in the head and neck (HNPGLs) and 95% do not secrete catecholamines or other hormones. The common types of HNPGL are carotid body, vagal and jugulotympanic. Sympathetic PGLs usually secrete catecholamines.

Key Takeaway - Medullary thyroid cancer is associated with calcitonin, Hepatoblastoma with AFP, Choriocarcinoma with Beta HCG, and Pheochromocytoma with catecholamines.

questions.text: An 84 year old man with a history of stroke 2 years ago, who is on prolonged bed rest and develops a pressure ulcer with partial thickness skin loss and a clean base. What is the grade of his sore?
questions.solution:
Pressure ulcers can be graded according to an internationally recognised grading system based on the extent of skin loss. Category 1 ulcers involve non-blanching erythema with intact skin. Category 2 ulcers have partial thickness skin loss and appear as a shallow open ulcer with a red-pink wound bed or an intact or ruptured serum-filled blister. Category 3 ulcers have full thickness skin loss, with subcutaneous fat visible in the wound, but not bone, tendon or muscle. Category 4 ulcers have full thickness loss with exposed bone, tendon or muscle; osteomyelitis may develop at these sites

Incorrect Choices Explanation

  • Choice A: Grade 1 - Grade 1 ulcers involve non-blanching erythema with intact skin, not partial thickness skin loss.
  • Choice C: Grade 3 - Grade 3 ulcers involve full thickness skin loss with visible subcutaneous fat, not just partial skin loss.
  • Choice D: Grade 4 - Grade 4 ulcers show full thickness skin loss with exposed bone, tendon, or muscle, often with complications such as osteomyelitis.

Key Takeaway - Grade 2 pressure ulcers involve partial thickness skin loss with a clean base.

questions.text: A 35-year-old male underwent surgery for an ileal perforation. Due to heavy contamination, only the sheath was closed and the wound was left open. Daily wound washing was performed, and the wound was closed on postoperative day 5. What mechanism does the wound healing occur in this case?
questions.solution:
Clean wounds with a good blood supply heal by primary intention and so closure simply requires accurate apposition of the wound edges. However, if a wound is left open, it heals by secondary intention through the formation of granulation tissue, which is tissue composed of capillaries, fibroblasts and inflammatory cells. Wound contraction and epithelialisation assist in ultimate healing, but the process may take several weeks or months. Delayed primary closure or tertiary intention is utilised when there is a high probability of the wound being infected. The wound is left open for a few days and if the infective process is resolved then the wound is closed to heal by primary intention. Skin grafting is another form of tertiary intention healing

Incorrect Choices Explanation

  • Choice A: Primary intention - Primary intention occurs when the wound is closed immediately with accurate apposition of the wound edges, without significant risk of infection, which is not the case in this scenario as the wound was left open initially.
  • Choice B: Secondary intention - Secondary intention occurs when a wound is left open and heals by the formation of granulation tissue, wound contraction, and epithelialization. This happens when closure is not possible or not done, which is not applicable here because the wound was closed after a few days.
  • Choice D: Quaternary intention - Quaternary intention is not a recognized term in wound healing.

Key Takeaway - Tertiary intention involves leaving a wound open initially due to infection risk, then closing it once infection is controlled.

choices.text: Epidural anesthesia is recommended in laparoscopic surgery for pain control
Reduction in hospital stay by 2-3 weeks
Beta blockers are given after major surgery under general anesthesia to improve outcomes

questions.text: One of your friends is teaching you about enhanced recovery after surgery. Which of the following he states is incorrect?
questions.solution:
ERAS is evidence based on the strong scientific rationale for avoiding unmodulated exposure to stress, prolonged fasting and excessive administration of intravenous (saline) fluids. ERAS principles are now applied by protocol to many types of major surgery, bringing considerable benefit in terms of improved outcomes. Reductions in length of hospital stay after surgery of 30-50% are common, with associated savings in healthcare costs. ERAS depends on a multimodal approach where the combined effects of several interventions achieve significant benefits. β-blockers are associated with improved short- and long-term survival after major surgery, perhaps by modulating the effects of the hyperadrenergic state induced by surgical stress. Equally, in "open" surgery the use of epidural analgesia to reduce pain, block the cortisol stress response and attenuate postoperative insulin resistance may, via effects on the body's protein economy, favourably affect many of the patient-centred outcomes that are important to postoperative recovery

Incorrect Choices Explanation

  • Choice B: Epidural anesthesia is recommended in laparoscopic surgery for pain control - Epidural anesthesia is often used for pain control in open surgery and is beneficial for managing pain and reducing the stress response, but it may not always be necessary for laparoscopic surgery, which typically involves less invasive procedures and pain.
  • Choice C: Reduction in hospital stay by 2-3 weeks - ERAS protocols have been shown to reduce hospital stays by 30-50% in some cases, which corresponds to a reduction in length of stay by about 2-3 days, not weeks.
  • Choice D: Beta blockers are given after major surgery under general anesthesia to improve outcomes - Beta blockers are given in ERAS protocols to improve outcomes by modulating the hyperadrenergic state induced by surgery. This can help reduce complications and improve short- and long-term survival.

Key Takeaway - Prolonged fasting is unnecessary in ERAS protocols, which focus on early feeding and minimizing unnecessary stressors for improved recovery.

choices.text: Development of pain on the 1st step of walking
Pain aggravated by standing and relieved by bending forward
Pain develops after walking some distance and is relieved by rest
Pain is more at night and sleep

questions.text: A chronic smoker comes with complaints of pain in the legs after walking 100 m. On examination, he has absent pulse in bilateral dorsalis pedis, anterior tibial and posterior tibial arteries but no gangrene is present. Intermittent claudication is implicated. Which of the following statements is true regarding his condition?
questions.solution:
Intermittent claudication occurs as a result of anaerobic muscle metabolism and is classically described as debilitating cramp-like pain felt in the muscles that is:

  • brought on by walking;
  • not present on taking the first step (unlike osteoarthritis);
  • relieved by rest in both the standing and sitting positions, usually within 5 minutes (unlike nerve compression from a lumbar intervertebral disc prolapse or osteoarthritis of the spine or spinal stenosis, which are typically relieved only when resting in the sitting position for longer than 5 minutes).

The distance that a patient is able to walk without stopping varies (claudication distance) only slightly from day to day. It is decreased, first, by increasing the work demands and hence oxygen requirements of the muscles affected, e.g. walking up hill, increasing the speed of walking and/or carrying heavy weights, and, second, by general health conditions that reduce the oxygen delivery capacity of the arterial system, e.g. anaemia or cardiorespiratory disease

Incorrect Choices Explanation

  • Choice A: Development of pain on the 1st step of walking - Pain developing on the first step of walking is more indicative of conditions like osteoarthritis or nerve compression. In intermittent claudication, the pain develops after walking for a distance.
  • Choice B: Pain aggravated by standing and relieved by bending forward - This description is more characteristic of spinal stenosis, where pain is aggravated by standing and relieved by bending forward, not by intermittent claudication.
  • Choice D: Pain is more at night and sleep - Nocturnal pain is a feature of more advanced stages of peripheral arterial disease or rest pain, which occurs due to severe arterial occlusion. This is different from intermittent claudication, where pain typically occurs with activity and is relieved by rest.

Key Takeaway - Intermittent claudication pain develops after walking a certain distance and is relieved by rest, usually within 5 minutes.

questions.text: What is the T stage for this oral cavity tumor?
questions.solution:
T4a refers to a tumor that has invaded nearby structures, such as the mandible, muscle, or skin. This stage is used when the tumor is large but still resectable. It indicates significant local spread but not distant metastasis.

Incorrect Choices Explanation

  • Choice B: T2 - T2 refers to a tumor that is larger than a T1 tumor but has not yet invaded deeper structures like the mandible or muscle. It typically indicates a tumor that is limited to the oral cavity but still localized.
  • Choice C: T3 - T3 refers to a tumor that is larger than T2, typically >4 cm, but still limited to the region without invasion into adjacent critical structures like bones or muscles.
  • Choice D: T4b - T4b indicates involvement of more critical structures such as the carotid artery or other deep neck structures, usually indicating an inoperable tumor with extensive spread.

Key Takeaway - T4a denotes a tumor with significant local invasion but still resectable, typically involving the mandible or surrounding muscles.

questions.text: Inflation during laparoscopy is done with the help of which instrument?
questions.solution: There are two fundamental ways to access the abdomen laparoscopically
